profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-12 10:22:03 -0700.

did.abstract: Synanon was founded by Charles Dederich, Sr. in 1958. Synanon's detoxification therapy attracted wealthy drug and alcohol abusers with chapters in San Francisco, Tulare and Marin Counties, Detroit, and as far as Germany and Malaysia. The collection consists of correspondence, recordings, films, video tapes, photographs, and printed materials related to the Synanon Foundation.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

No copying (except by hand notes and/or note taking with a personal computer) for any purposes, including publication, or use for commercial purposes permitted without prior written approval by the Trustees of the Synanon Archives Trust, which retains copyright to the Synanon records. The names of Synanon members or residents shall not be revealed or used, nor shall members or residents be contacted unless prior written approval has been granted by the Trustees of the Synanon Archives Trust.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIO AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed audio and audiovisual materials. Audio and audiovisual materials are not currently available for access, unless otherwise noted in a Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of some audiovisual materials are available for viewing in the Library Special Collections reading room.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of The Synanon Church, Incorporated, 1993.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Synanon Foundation records (Collection 342). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Synanon was founded by Charles Dederich, Sr. in 1958; originally named TLC (Tender Loving Care Club), the group was renamed Synanon and had its headquarters in Santa Monica, California; Synanon's detoxification therapy attracted wealthy drug and alcohol abusers, and eventually the organization became a $30 million nonprofit organization; chapters sprang up in San Francisco, Tulare and Marin Counties, Detroit, and as far as Germany and Malaysia; Dederich declared Synanon a religion in 1974; Dederich was forced to give up control of Synanon in 1979 after pleading no contest to conspiracy to commit murder; Synanon quickly lost its popularity thereafter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of the records of the Synanon Foundation. Includes correspondence, recordings, films, video tapes, photographs, and printed materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synanon archive #252. Side of can labeled: "A-13 - S.F. Anniversary - Orig. - Outs - Pic - 1972" Appears to be outtakes related to Synanon celebrating an anniversary of collaborating with NL Industries in San Francisco. NL Industries gave Synanon their old paint factory location in 1970, to which Synanon moved from their Seawall location in San Francisco. Film features press conference with Channel 7 microphones and KQED cameras visible. Wooden house with broken windows and sign "People Live Here." People dancing and band performing in elaborate costumes. Signs shown: "NLI + Synanon = A Nice Thing for San Francisco", "You Made it Possible - NL Industries / Synanon", Synanon: Recycling People and Buildings" Channel 5 microphone and KPIX 5 logo visible during production shots.

physdesc.physfacet: Footage starts abruptly after leader. Might be missing footage at head. Very scratched throughout, though worse predominantly at head. Tear near tail with poor condition tape splice repair - left during inspection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synanon archive #156a. Inside Consolidated Film Industries box labeled: "CFI Original - Do Not Project" and "Santa Monica Wedding - Orig. - Pic. - 1973" Likely film of Synanon wedding ceremony in Santa Monica in 1973, one year after the main Synanon Wedding Festival in northern California in 1972. Group on beach at golden hour - very beautiful! Procession on beach outside Del Mar building. Gathered on top of Del Mar building: couples embracing, kissing. Inside, sitting in circle. Ceremony inside with mostly floral print clothes. Many out of focus shots.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rehoused previously by UCLA staff with note added: "Thickened Light Day - Orig. - Pic. - 1972" added to lid. Footage of some kind of outdoor festival, with music, clowns, facepainting, and more. "Thickened Light" comes from an Emerson quote and appears to have been adopted by Synanon and used as the basis of an internal holiday, Thickened Light Day. "Thickened Light Demonstration" shown with elaborate diagrams on chalkboard. Synanon water tower indicates San Francisco.

Animated opening title: "Lightweight Lighting / 30 Jun 70" Credits end with line "We're all goin' to jail." Appears to be instructional film and includes close-ups on light equipment and light meter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synanon archive #183. "E-16 Tomales Construction - Workprint - Pic - 1973" Cows in shadow or out of focus, filmed from barn. Likely filmed in Tomales Bay, Marin County where Synanon owned land and built ranches.

did.unittitle: Walker Creek Construction: Camera Original and Work Print

physdesc.physfacet: Dot matrix "STOP" printed in at head (over image). A few frames later, two small holes punched in frame at head. Camera issues near tail causing frames to blur out of proper registration. Frame counts printed on edge of film. / Significant base scratching primarily on one of the sprocket sides (and therefore not in the image much). Light emulsion scratching in middle of frame. / Uncut film. / Some tape residue on film from original tape. Printed in edge information: "Ektachrome EFB 7 Safety Film" with same date code. / Base scratching mostly on edges with sprocket holes. / Likely camera issues causing frames to blur out of proper registration. Single frames of black leader have been spliced in between throughout reel, possibly to replace blurred frames. / Mostly black film with short segments of content near tail. Single black frames have been interpolated. Due to fleeting nature of film segments, stock could only be identified as from Kodak without further information about stock or date. Likely 1972.

Edge damage mostly previously repaired with tape. Kodachrome stock only using for black leader spacing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Synanon archive #186. In Palmer Film Services paper bag inside can. Bag labeled: "Title 'Chinatown Must Change Now' - Property of Marilynn Aiches - Feet: 563 - Black and White - (1) 7302 B.+W. Electro Sound Release Print - Client's old answer print" Student film made about protests at San Francisco State College (University, now) in fall 1968. Focuses on student group Intercollegiate Chinese for Social Action and their combination with Third World Liberation Front. Directed by Marilynn Aiches with David Hilberman (The Synanon People Ranch and othersl) as faculty advisor. This may explain why this is in the collection. No information about film available online.

Communal dinner scene. All lit and exposed well.

scopecontent.p: Synanon archive #200. In padded "Jiffy" envelope address to [...], KSFO, [...]. KPIX 5 address label. Handwritten on label: "Wedding - Do Not Project." Postmarked in San Francisco, August 15, 1972. Appears to be news coverage from KPIX 5 (microphone visible in interviews) of the Wedding Festival. This footage does not appear to match that in "The Synanon Wedding Festival."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed-in handwriting at head and tail: "CBS-TVR Meadowlane Prod. Jazz Scene #7" and "CBS - Jazz Scene #7" Tail leader: "Jazz Scene / Sounds of Synanon" Episode #7 of TV series "Jazz Scene USA" produced by CBS Los Angeles. Hosted by Oscar Brown, Jr. Features Sounds of Synanon band playing in-studio, including guitarist Joe Pass. Kaleidoscope optical effect during one song. Brown explains Synanon with images and reel includes "Life at Synanon" segment, which appears to match content of "Synanon at 1351" reel (yrlsc_342_723_005) Band interviewed with Sounds of Synanon LP prominently displayed. Last song is "C.E.D." and a picture of Chuck Dederich is shown to introduce it.

did.unittitle: Bay to Breakers: Camera Original Outtakes

physdesc.physfacet: 23 individual segments of film found wrapped around each other and spliced together with small sections of leader in between, with attempt to retain order in which film was wrapped. First 18 sections are silent. Final 5 sections were wound together in middle of larger reel with label "MISS. SHOTS." Three of these sections have sound, while the final two sections are silent again (GAF stock). Some sections had tape residue that was cleaned off with alcohol. In some cases redox blemishes have appeared on emulsion side where tape was.

H27 / #61 / 8-08-80" Note inside can identifies contents as "H-27 SYNANON - ITS TENTH YEAR, NBC-TV, 10-9-68, color, 7:36 min. Later generation copy of yrlsc_342_723_002, but uncut and with fewer scratches. Color quality less good in this copy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Palmer Film Services label on can: "Title: Synanon at 1351 - 1962 or '63 . Footage of beach, diningroom, game and Band / Silent / Running time: 3:00 / Black and white silent" Second label: "Orig # H5 / Audit + Visual #28 / Print / Title: Footage of beach, dining room, game - 1352" Side of can labeled: "H5 Synanon on 1351" Synanon Department of Films green "Protect-a-Print" leader at head, followed by clear film labeled: "Jazz Scene U.S.A." Printed-in handwriting at tail: "A Roll - Foot - Synanon Documentary" and red "Do not rewind" leader at tail. 1351 Ocean Front, Santa Monica, was address of National Guard armory building that Synanon took over. Shots of Synanon House sign. Chuck Dederich and others sitting around table inside. Close-ups on signboards with job assignments. Band playing music at end. Appears to have been edited into "Jazz Scene USA - Sounds of Synanon" (yrlsc_342_587_005), with music score performed by the Sounds of Synanon band in that program.

physdesc.physfacet: Small segments of film previously loosely taped together. Now spliced together with leader slugs in between. Tape splices for mag stripe only made on non-mag side. Reel starts with 1971 TXR mag stripe film and switches to double perf silent 1972 PXR approximately halfway through reel. Persistent base scratch throughout reel.

Bottom of can labeled: "JUNE / 'Upward Mobility' / 'Getting the News Past Fresno' / 'T.B. Tanker'" Three news stories: "Upward Mobility"; "Getting the News Past Fresno" including "Welcome back Chuck and Betty" party/reception, a recorded Game session with shots of Sony TC-106A tape recorder, office with sign "The Game: Synanon's Government"; and last story "Tanker (Tomales Bay)" featuring Synanon Fire Department truck driving from city to Tomales Bay ranch. End credit: "Synanon on Film - an Oakland Movie Lot production"

Outs - Pic - 1972" Sign identifies "Great Scrambled Egg Eating Contest" with weigh-in on October 6 and context on Octover 7 in "the Lot." Men sitting at table eating while spectators watch.
